arm_group.description:
basic recipe for juice and muffin recipe
abbreviated PLB

The supplements were prepared as two fruit juice mixtures (each 270 ml) providing 7 g total fiber/d) and two small muffins providing 9 g total fiber/d for 16 g of toal fiber daily.
abbreviated CMC

The supplements were prepared as two fruit juice mixtures (each 270 ml) providing 7 g total fiber/d) and two small muffins providing 9 g total fiber/d for 16 g of toal fiber daily.
abbreviated GA

The supplements were prepared as two fruit juice mixtures (each 270 ml) providing 7 g total fiber/d) and two small muffins providing 9 g total fiber/d for 16 g of toal fiber daily.
abbreviated as PSY

brief_summary.textblock:
The primary aim of this study was to compare the effects of supplementation with one of
      three dietary fibers (gum arabic, carboxy-methylcellulose, or psyllium) or a placebo on
      fecal incontinence (FI), symptom intolerance, and quality of life in community-living
      individuals who have incontinence of loose or liquid feces.  A secondary aim was to explore
      the possible mechanism(s) underlying the supplements' efficacy (i.e., improvements in stool
      consistency, water-holding capacity or gel formation).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age ≥18 years

          -  living in the community (not a nursing home or assisted living facility)

          -  self-report of usually having FI of loose or liquid consistency at least twice in a
             2-wk period

          -  toilets independently

          -  ability to read and write in English.

          -  Persons that regularly performed pelvic floor muscle exercises and/or biofeedback on
             a maintenance regimen for at least 20 wks or who took a steady dose of anti-motility
             medications on a regular schedule that still met the FI criteria were also eligible.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  difficulty swallowing,

          -  a gastrointestinal (GI) tract altered by surgery,

          -  a malabsorption disorder,

          -  inflammatory bowel disease,

          -  gastrointestinal cancer or active cancer treatment,

          -  allergy to the fibers,

          -  regularly used a laxative or enema, were tube-fed, or unwilling to discontinue taking
             periodic self-prescribed fiber supplements or anti-diarrheal medications.

          -  a score  ≤24 on the Mini Mental State Examination

          -  having/reporting fewer than two episodes of FI or being incapable of performing study
             procedures during the run-in baseline period

clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Fiber Fermentation on Fecal Incontinence

other_outcome.description: the Stool Consistency Classification System used was shown to be valid and reliable
other_outcome.measure: self-reported rating of consistency of continent stools on a daily stool diary

other_outcome.description: written record of all food and drink consumed
subjects checked whether the drank required amount of additional fluid and wrote the date and time of drinking
subjects indicated number of absorbent products that were soiled on stool diary and and saved and returned them to be assessed by study team
reported on stool diary daily with reason for not collecting
other_outcome.measure: self-report of any stools not collected

other_outcome.description: date and time a stool color change was observed after swallowing a capsule with a decoy or marker dose of a food dye; date and time capsule was taken was also reported
nested experiment of in vitro degradation of each dietary fiber by stools of subjects using established procedure reported in Bliss, D.Z. et al. Nurs. Res. 2001, 50, 203-213.
established method of Theander O. et al. J AOAC Int. 1995;78(4):1030-44 used.
other_outcome.measure: total dietary fiber content of fiber sources used in Study
Personal Goals of Treatment for Fecal Incontinence and Satisfaction with Achievement of Goals
modifications of preparation of foods, diet intake, and eating pattern to manage fecal incontinence

overall_official.affiliation: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

primary_outcome.description: the date and time of an incontinence episode was reported and the ratio of the number of incontinence episodes to total stools daily was calculated
primary_outcome.measure: self-report of an incontinent episode on a daily stool diary

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description:
The amount of GI symptoms reported were flatus, belching, bloating, abdominal cramping, nausea, a feeling of fullness, and stomach upset using a categorical scale. Number of times of flatus was also reported.
The amount of two obfuscating symptoms were also reported. headache and sleepiness.
How upsetting/bothersome the symptoms were were also reported.
secondary_outcome.measure: self-report of gastro-intestinal symptoms on a daily symptom record

secondary_outcome.description: The Fecal Incontinence Quality of Life tool (FIQL) was used;  Rockwood, T.H. et al. Diseases of the Colon & Rectum. 2000;43(1):9-16.
Measure was done on stools of 52 randomly selected subjects (13 from each group) Established method of Wenzl, H. et al. Gastroenterology. 1995;108(6):1729-38 used.
secondary_outcome.measure: Water-holding capacity of non-frozen of stools

secondary_outcome.description: Measure was done on stools of 52 randomly selected subjects (13 from each group); Established method of Fischer, M.H. et al.Carbohydrate Research 2004;339(11): 2009-2017.

Measured in composites of all stools from baseline and supplement periods and non-frozen stools
Established method of Theander O, et al. J AOAC Int. 1995;78(4):1030-44 used.
secondary_outcome.measure: Total dietary fiber content of feces

secondary_outcome.description: reported by fractions on supplement intake form and return of unconsumed portion was assessed by study team
secondary_outcome.measure: Self-report of amount of supplement consumed

secondary_outcome.description: subjects self-reported greatest amount of soiling (from soling of tissue between buttocks to shoes or floor)
collected stools were weighed and freeze-dried to constant weight; percentage of water content was calculated from these values
secondary_outcome.measure: wet and dry weights of collected stools and percentage of water content

clinical_study.source: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Minnesota - Clinical and Translational Science Institute

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Factorial Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment
